title: R42389
content: Child support is a cash payment that noncustodial parents must pay for their children's financial support. The Child Support Enforcement (CSE) program, established in 1975, aims to secure consistent financial support for children from their noncustodial parent and help families remain self-sufficient. The program is based on the idea that both parents are financially responsible for their children, with states administering it and the federal government playing a significant role in program design and funding. The CSE program, established in 1975, aims to secure financial support for children from noncustodial parents. States administer the program with federal government involvement in funding and program design. The program has evolved into a family-first service delivery model, emphasizing the well-being of families by ensuring reliable child support payments. States use various methods, including the threat of jail, to collect child support obligations. Many states treat failure to pay child support as contempt of court, which can be a civil or criminal offense. Contempt of court can result in punishment for violating court orders, with contempt classified as civil or criminal depending on the purpose of the penalty imposed. Civil contempt is when an individual willfully disobeys a court order or rule, leading to potential fines or jail time to coerce compliance with the court order. This is commonly used in family law to enforce child support orders that have been violated. In civil contempt, courts enforce child support orders by potentially sending the noncustodial parent to jail unless they comply with payment. Criminal contempt of court occurs when an individual interferes with court proceedings, such as yelling at the judge or jury. Punishments for criminal contempt may include fines, jail time, or both. These charges are separate from the underlying case and are meant to deter future acts of contempt. Unlike civil contempt, criminal contempt charges can persist even after the underlying case is resolved. It is often difficult to classify acts as civil or criminal contempt of court.
